item.description:
The object is to find a word that begins with two letters.

On each card, a little phrase has a word in white. Each player or team has a few chips that show two letters. It should be the first to announce a valid word, starting with those letters, to complete the sentence. A word may be refused by a vote of players. Who complete the sentence first may remove one of his token out of his supply. 
The first player who has no more tokens left wins the game

Second compilation of ten games with three classics (f.e. Hangman) and seven other "unpublished" games.

The Boutamot:
An original word game, where a coil is formed of words that begin with the end of the previous word. The more we make big words, the more we encroach on the previous word, the more you score points.

The Tower 
Word game with anagrams. At first we wrote a letter, then two, then three and so on. There is a phase five letters and six letters in which he must find a new word, changing only one letter. The first player who can not find the next word loses the game.

Snake Apple :
Tactical game inspired by the game of the Worms.

The Rides:
Car race on a circuit of hexagons. As in car racing on paper, you can change gears at every turn respecting a + or - 1.

The Beach 
Mysterious interesting deduction game inspired by the naval battle. Five traps and three treasures are on a beach. We need to find the treasures in less than 100 blows. After each trip, the encoder indicates whether objects are nearby ... or if you jumped on a trap.

There are 10 different games in this box with three classic games (f.e. the naval battle) and seven more unknown titles.

Even / Odd:
is an interesting tactical game, where players take turns to move numbers on a squares adjacent to occupied squares. The goal is to catch the opponentby playing in a box completely surrounded by occupied squares.

The crossword puzzle: 
according to a original rules, each in turn wrote two more letters on a grid to score as many points as possible by lengthening words or creating new ones.

The secret message: 
game of deduction and letters.

The architect:
Players move into a house of four levels, while building stairs, doors and windows. Each piece can contain only three elements. Once a player can no longer build or move, he lost the game.

The yacht race is an attempt to adapt a set of sailing race mode pen and paper. Interesting but tedious.

name.value: Wickie und die starken Männer: Wickie und der Piratenschatz

item.description:
Objective: get as much as possible from the gold of 'The terrible Sven' or (as Sven) protect/get back your gold
 - moving/acting by turn -
1. place gold coins on the island (typically 4x number of players) - starting point: each player's drake
2. 'Sven' gets one shark for each opponent (decelarates movement), each player gets a dolphin (in his/her own colour)
3. movement: 1d6 move horizontal or vertical - sharks and other players block you, ending on your own dolphin ==> use movment points for the second time; a '6' let you move a shark and a dolphin (free of choice) additionally... get to gold island and catch one gold coin & row back
4. end of turn ==> Sven's turn: 2d6; if he catches a player with a gold coin on the sea ==> player is sent back to starting positon & looses the coin; Sven gets the coin
5. if players/Sven get back to their drakes they can store the loot safely and continue the hunt 
6. game ends after last coin was safed

content: board, 5 meeples, 5 boats, 60 gold coins, 4 dolphins, 4 sharks, 2 dice, rules

Objective: be the first getting rid of all your cards
 - acting by turn - 
1. put all five '1' cards face up into middle of the desk, take out the donkey card; all other cards are shuffled and handed out
2. each player forms a pile, cards face down
3. draw top card; if you can discard it - must match colour & must show a value of +1 (='2' in the very first moment/round) put it into the middle ==> form a pile
3a. if it doesn't match ==> form your open pile next to you... ==> next player's turn
4. draw top card; if you can discard it - must match colour & must show a value of +1 ==> desk pile (priority!) 
OR ==> must show a value of +/- 1 & no need of matching colour to place on top open pile of one of your opponents
5. if your face down pile is empty turn your open pile face down 
6. if active player misses an opportunity to discard or plays wrong sequence ==> gets penalty: donkey card & 1 card from each opponent 
content: 100 cards numbered 1-20/5 colours

+ 1 donkey & 3 joker cards

remarks:
less enjoyable with 2 players

START YOUR ENGINES!
 A major corporation has come to today’s race looking for a team of drivers to sponsor. Unlike other sponsors, this corporation is not looking for a team that only cares about winning; they want a team that gets the crowd’s blood pumping with incredible speeds and daring maneuvers. A gutsy driver is just as likely to be remembered as a winning driver.
 Race Fans is a family card game for 1-4 people that has players controlling a team of race car drivers trying to gain fans and win a major corporate sponsorship.

Race Fans is designed to be fast, fun, and easy to learn. The game revolves around 8 race cars in a row called the track. During the game, players use one of two different cards to affect the cars in an attempt to gain fans. Maneuver cards are used to change the position of the race cars on the track while thrill cards are used to gain fans.

Shadow Era is the physical world edition of the electronic multi-platform collectible card game by the same name. The initial (physical) release was crowd funded and contains the first set of 200 cards.

In this fantasy world of the Shadow creatures have fallen over the realm of mankind. The player assumes the role of a powerful character on either side and fights his enemies using a customized deck of cards.

Each deck contains a hero card with a different special ability and number of hit points. A player loses the game when his character's life drops to zero. Each turn players may sacrifice a card from their hand to build their resources and then use those resources to play cards or execute abilities. Cards can be allies with which to attack the opposing side, abilities such as spells and items including weapons and armor.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

item.description:
Players draw a card without looking it and put it on their headband.
They ask as many questions as possible in the limited time to guess the picture on the card: animal, vegetable, fruit, object? 
By asking questions to other players they cannot answer with "yes","no" or" maybe".
For each card guessed, you eliminate a token.
The first player who gets rid of his tokens wins the game.

Similar to:

 Amnesia
 Am I a Banana?
 Who am I?

The game is based on the film Finding Nemo, specifically scene in which the father tries to get Nemo back. Players play as Nemo’s father and need to collect the words “M A R L I N” in order. This is a print and play game.

In each round, a 6 sided dice is rolled to determine the movement of father. Then players should collect the words “M A R L I N” in order. The player hove to land exactly on the words, not pass through them. You can’t return the way. If you pass through jellyfish, you have to miss a turn. When you reach Nigel’s box, roll the dice to the goal. With odd numbers, you can finish. But with even numbers, you have to move to seagull box. The player that reaches Nemo first is the winner.

Have you ever tried to manage a community of gnomes? This is quite a difficult task as they are hard to control and they usually do whatever they want.

Gnominia puts the players in charge of managing a village inhabited by gnomes and have them competing with other villages. The first player who manages to gain 20 trophies is declared winner.

A game for 1-4 players with a dynamic set-up which allows for ever-changing experiences, Gnominia is a dice interpretation of the deck-/pool-building concept made so popular by games such as Dominion or Ascension. Every player starts with an identical set-up for his village and can activate the various buildings using a set of three dice. During the game, various cards may be purchased to modify the village, allowing for different dice results. Players can also hire mercenaries, found guilds, upgrade their buildings, complete missions, and cast spells in order to gain trophies and win the game. All of this in frantic twenty-minute game...

item.description:
Promotional game by Flunch, a reastaurant chain in France.

It play like War in that you challenge each other in a turn and the most powerful card 'captures' the enemy card. There is a difference here in that a special die is also used. Every time you reveal a card, you roll a die and the value of the die rolled is added to the value on the card. So you can never be sure of a victory in any challenge.

The winner is the player who wins all the cards.

Kampen om Norge ("The Battle of Norway") is a strategy board game about the German invasion of Norway in 1940. Each player takes control of the armed forces of either Norway, The Allies, or Germany. Using plastic soldier playing pieces that represent armies, and cards that represent war ships, bombers, fighters and special actions, the players battle for control of the six victory cities on the board. Managing the resources you get from your playing cards is crucial to succeed.

The game is fast-paced and has a quick set-up, yet offers a wide range of strategic options and variations. The starting point of the game and the resources available to the different factions are based on the historical conditions, but the players have the chance to change the course of history. Kampen om Norge is suitable for 2–3 players (or teams) and is playable in 2–3 hours.


Den 9. april 1940 overfaller tyske stridskrefter et nøytralt og dårlig forberedt Norge. Felttoget i Norge er høyt spill, men Hitler har bestemt seg for å legge landet under jernhælen. Norske og allierte styrker mobiliserer og nekter å gi seg uten kamp. Klarer de å stanse det tyske stormløpet?

Dette er utgangspunktet for strategispillet Kampen om Norge, et spennende brettspill om den tyske invasjonen i 1940, som gir spillerne mulighet til å utøve historiekunnskap i praksis. Tidenes første norske strategi-krigsspill er lekkert utført med naturtro brikker, realistiske spillekort og et detaljert kart.

Hver spiller påtar seg rollen som øverstkommanderende for de militære styrkene til Norge, de allierte eller Tyskland. Ved hjelp av brikker, terninger og spillekort utkjemper spillerne en kamp seg imellom på brettet, der Norge og de allierte sammen må forsøke å stoppe Tysklands frammarsj på norsk jord og hindre at Tyskland okkuperer alle de viktige byene. Spillerne må ta strategiske valg, forvalte ressursene på spillekortene, flytte sine bataljoner omkring på spillebrettet og kjempe mot motstanderen om landområdene. Den som velger den smarteste strategien, har best sjanse til å vinne, men det hjelper også å være venn med terningene.

Kampen om Norge kan spilles i to vanskelighetsgrader.

 - acting/moving by turn -
roll the die, move & draw action card;
if you support/feed your pet well it is speeding up, otherwise it will slow down/step backwards

pocket edition 2-4 players
large edition (title changing to: Champion of the great dog/cat/rabit race) 2-7 players

For 38 years Jim Knopf, his friend Lukas the railway man, Emma the locomotive and all their friends have taken children to Lummerland. This game leads players to three different locations, Lummerland, Kummerland and Mandala, and of course the kidnapped princess LiSi must be freed. The game is based on the concept in Michael Endes stories of cooperation and the joint efforts against adversities. The die brings luck into the game and Emma suspension, because players need to be in the company of Emma when the pass the finish line, but Emma tends to run away to another player in the last moment.
Monopoly set in Euskirchen in Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.

In Ni Oui Ni Non: Nature, players need to answer questions as quickly as possible – but without saying "yes" or "no". Can they do it? Yes or no? Um, I mean, is it possible or will they fail?

Each round, one player picks a question card — with questions for a child or adult depending on who she intends to confront — then she chooses a victim and starts peppering the player with questions. If the victim ever utters "yes" or "no" when answering, the first player to slap the bell advances her token on the game board. If the victim hesitates too long or answers only with the same vague responses, such as "I don't know", slap that bell! If the victim makes it through the questioning without uttering the forbidden words, however, then she advances on the track. The first player to reach the center of the game board wins.

Ni Oui Ni Non: Nature includes more than 900 questions about animals and nature.

900 questions about geography.

Object of the game is during the questions try other players
to answer forbidden words YES or NO. If somebody answer so
others must then quickly ring the bell to move their pawn on the gameboard if they are the quickest.

The winner is who gets there first with his character in the middle of the board.

Contents:

 1 game board,
 110 cards, including 55 for children (orange) and 55 adult (green),
 1 bell,
 6 characters.

Similar to headband games but there are masks instead of headbands.

Put a mask on your head without looking at what it is and guess what animal You are.
Asks questions to other players to find if you're a cow, a monkey or another!
15 funny animals for children to have fun finding out who they are.
Monopoly set to Günzburg, Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.

Splink (SP + link) is a ball-stacking game that can be played with a Shibumi set, as it uses a 4x4 holes board and balls in two colours (white and red).

RULES

2 players ('attractor' and 'repulsor') share a supply of 16 red and 16 white balls.

Splink has two types of game play:

- Duel: The players play two complete games, switching roles after the first game. Whoever gets the maximum score as the 'attractor' wins.

- Bid: Before the game starts, players take turns increasing bids as to how many ponts they think they can make playing the 'attractor' role. The player who passes first plays the 'repulsor'; the other player plays the 'attractor' and must get as many points as he bid to win.

The board starts empty. Starting with 'attractor', players take turns either:

a) placing TWO balls, one of each colour, on ANY TWO valid locations (empty spaces or 2x2 platforms) or...

b) removing a ball from the board that supports exactly ONE ball on the level above and placing a new one of the other colour from the supply onto the board on any valid location; even on top of the dropped balls. Notice that you can only do this action if there is at least one ball on the supply of a different colour of the ball that you want to remove.

GAME END

The game ends when the pyramid has been completed.

SCORING

To get the attractor's score, count the number of all different red-white visible connections on the pyramid (the 5 inner balls don't count for connections). A red ball and a white ball must be touching to consider it a connection.

VARIANT

Consider an unlimited supply for both colours.

Included in the Shibumi Rule Book

Soft cover:

http://www.lulu.com/shop/cameron-browne-and-nestor-romeral-andres/shibumi-rule-book/paperback/product-18940123.html

Downloadable PDF:

http://www.nestorgames.com/rulebooks/SHIBUMI_EN.pdf

item.description:
Based on the classic action game Rebound, Rebound Ramp It Up adds a new dimension. The second half of the board is height adjustable, with pits at each scoring ledge. The scoring ledges are worth 100, 200, 300 or 400 points. At the top of the ramp is a bonus basket that is worth 600 points. Each player has three pucks to score with. The first player to reach 3000 points is the winner.

There are 3 game options:

High Point (for 2 players) - Players earn points by landing on the scoring ledges. Pucks that fall into the pits score zero points.

Slam Dunk (for 2 players) - Players only earn points by landing in the pits. Pucks not in a pit score zero points.

Solo Slinger (for 1 player) - The player tries to score 3000 points in the fewest number of rounds, using all six points. Pucks landing in a pit score zero points.

Re-implements:

 Rebound

name.value: Fairfax's Revenge: the battle of Langport 1645

item.description:
Introductory game for the English Civil War series by TCS Games, it is a small print & play wargame on this minor battle from the English Civil War, more a fighting retreat and a sequence of cavalry clashes than a complete battle.

The game features the now classic system from TCS, made of random chit draw leaders activation, based on the quality of the leader himself, that leads to units activation and subsequent movement and combat.
Each leader is rated from 1 to 3 (the higher the better, as he has more chance to be drawn earlier); when his chit is drawn from the pool, the player may move and have combat with all the units under his command. The activation is renewed for each other leader in the pool, except the last one that didn't move on that turn. there are no zone of controls (so movement is very fluid), terrain plays an important effect (as some terrain gives restriction to the attacker and improve the chances of the defender), combat is fast and furious (with advance, retreat and immediate elimination).

There are rules for melee, morale, cavalry charges, artillery and so on, with a very streamlined system that you may read and play in a few minutes.

Very good for introducing new players to the hobby, a sort of SPI quad games revisited and modernized

Sacramentum Gladiatorum is a game recreating gladiatorial combat in the arena in ancient Rome.

Turns are played simultaneously by players. In the first step, they will plan the move or the action for each gladiator. In the second step, they will reveal their orders and apply the results.

Combats are also planned using counters to determine where the gladiator will hit his opponent and how he will protect himself.

The location of hits is then reported to the part of the body chosen and general vitality of the gladiator will decrease.

name.value: Fist Fight Club: The Dice Game

item.description:
Fist Fight Club – The Dice Game (FFC) is a custom dice game for some fast and furious fist fight action with your mates.

Designed to be a fast play game, FFC is perfect for filling those times when other games are just too long (you know, like when your at your games club and have ten minutes to kill with your mates, or when you're waiting for a train).

How does it play? Well, here is the abridged version for two player games:

Players have 6 custom dice each, these dice have attack and defence icons on. They roll the dice to build up a 'fighting hand' with which to fight each other. Of the 6 dice, 3 are on show to all, three are kept secret.

The attacking players attack by playing one of their dice that shows an attack value. The defending player must play a die that shows the correct defense value to counter the attack value played on them. The attacker then plays a die with an attack value that counters the defense die just played by the defender.

This continues until one player is unable to play a die. If the defender can't play a die, they take a point of damage.

For games of more than 2 players, the actions gets even more intense as players attack who they want with the winner being the player with the least amount of damage taken when the first player to take all their damage is knocked out. So, attacking the player with the most damage isn't always the best tactic!

Capable of filling just as little as 5 minutes for two players but capable of being a big as you want. The more players you add, the more fun it is.

Being compact, it's easy to always having FFC with you. This means you and your mates never end up sitting around with nothing to do at your local club/store as you wait for your opponents to turn up. Just get out your dice and throw down with some mates for some real ‘underground fight club’ action as a warm up for your main event!

Objective: be the first to pass finish line
 - moving by turns -
simple 'Roll & Move' game;
each player throws the die moving forward; ending on a marked space follow instuctions of rule sheet.
Remarks:
game has two seperate boards which show north & middle region of W-Germany
printed ~ mid. 1950's

The first ever game that actually plays out the Hunt for the Great White from JAWS (1975)! Out of the only handful of games made about JAWS since 1975, none of them have been about or represented the events from the first Jaws film.

1-3 players play the Orca ship deck, 1 player plays the JAWS deck. The Orca deck wants to run the JAWS deck out of cards with various weapons, flotation barrels, a shark proof cage, strychnine, etc. During the hunt the Orca players can be expected to drink, sing, fish, work together and back stab each other. The time of day can change as the hunt progresses as well as the Orca's distance from shore.

The JAWS deck wants to eat the Orca crew, consisting of Quint (Robert Shaw), Hooper (Richard Dreyfuss), and Brody (Roy Scheider)! No better way to do this then by sinking the Orca first! Each deck has its own unique way of winning.

Everything that happens during the last hour of JAWS (1975) is in this game. Everything!

From the website:

"The game's objective is to become mayor and keep the post of mayor, which obviously gives certain advantages during the game. This is done by collecting votes throughout the game.

Besides the mayor title, it is also to acquire the city's businesses and create jobs for the city. This allows power and affects on each player's ability to gather votes. Money means a lot in the game, but is certainly not the decisive element. It's about playing the game tactically and be part of an alliance at the right time. The player can sit on power at one moment and sit with almost nothing the next minute. It is therefore important to constantly be alert and keep up with what opponents are doing. 2-6 participants. From approx. 9 years. Younger children may have practical roles. The game duration is about 100 min..."

Commercial Concept: The concept of Bormesterspillet is very simple. The city's enterprises and businesses buy advertising space on the local board. The prices for advertising slots vary by size.

Source: [www.borgmesterspil.dk The Game Website].

In YerTurn! each player, one at a time, draws a 'create' card and attempts to mold the object featured on the card with modeling dough. Other players attempt to guess the object the creator is molding. The player who guessed the object and the player who created the object will advance on the board. Special 'turn' cards are drawn when a player lands on a YerTurn! space; these cards include actions (double up, smash, lose a turn, etc) for use immediately or to save for later. Play consists of moving through the spaces on the board and being first to the final space!

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bamberg, in Germany.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Aschaffenburg, in Germany.

French abstract strategy game for 2-4 players.

A chess/ draughts type game played on a board of hexagonal spaces, where the aim is to ‘secure’ the central group in order to place one of your towers there, or to capture all of the enemy towers. Securing the central group can be achieved by Majority or Totality.

If aiming for a ‘Majority’:

 With two players you must occupy 5 of the 6 hexes in the central group.
 With three players you must occupy 4 of them.
 With four player you must occupy 3 of them




If aiming for ‘Totality’:
You must occupy at least one hex of the central group with the rest being completely empty of opposing pawns.

To win by either of the above methods the player must place
one of his towers in the central hex, which takes ‘a turn’. Victory can also be achieved by capturing all of the opposing towers thereby leaving you opponent without a tower to place in the central blank hex.

name.value: The Game of LIFE: zAPPed Edition

item.description:
As in the Original Game of Life, the goal of the game is to collect the most money by the time you retire at the end. The difference is that this new version of the Game of LIFE uses an iPad combined with a traditional gameboard. The free app brings your game to life as you move around the board. You still get to move your car from space to space and select your path to retirement, but now you spin, get paid, sue other players and make important decisions all on your iPad. While some spaces have traditional actions, if you land on app spaces, you unlock more than 100 clips from America’s Funniest Home Video. Find out if these videos bring you good fortune or bad luck.

This game requires the LIFE ZappED iPad application.

Tactical Second World War game simulating a British battalion attacking a reduced German battalion in 1943-45. Published in the book Simulating War. Components are also available from the author's website. The designer recommends playing with seven players in two teams.

The game is played on a 6x8 hex grid, each hex representing about 150 meters across. Units are platoons, divided into four British companies versus two smaller German companies. The British side also has a machinegun platoon. Both sides are supported by off-map mortars. Terrain tiles are randomly placed before play to make a unique map for each game.

Players take turn moving and firing with all their units. There are limits on cooperation between units from different companies. Successful fire attacks pin enemy units, preventing them from firing or moving during their next turn.

Victory is decided by elimination of enemy units. The British player also scores points for moving units to the opposite board edge.

Devine tÃªte version with celebrities.
Players draw a card without looking it and put it on their headband.
They ask as many questions as possible in the limited time to guess the celebrity on their card.
By asking questions to other players they cannot answer with "yes","no" or" maybe".
For each card guessed, you eliminate a token.
The first player who gets rid of his tokens wins the game.

2nd in the series of Touhou Shisouroku, a crossover between the fantasy world of Gensokyo and Dominion.

A standalone expansion featuring 25 new kingdom cards pooled from various Dominion expansions such as Intrigue, Prosperity and Cornucopia.

Gameplay is exactly the same as Dominion, where players purchase cards from a common pool and utilise them to accrue the largest number of victory points at the end of the game.

In Gensokyo, people relax and bask in the calm of a winter without end. Spring has shown no sign of arriving even though it's already May, and in fact the snowstorms are continually getting worse. Reimu Hakurei, a shrine maiden of the Hakurei Shrine, is tired of being cold day in and day out and wants to find the source of this unnatural weather. Marisa Kirisame, a black-clothed magician, sees a cherry blossom petal float down outside her warm house and wonders if spring is happening somewhere else. Sakuya Izayoi, the maid leader of the Scarlet Devil Mansion, knows that their winter supplies are diminishing quickly, and wants to end this prolonged winter before they run out completely.

Taken from en.touhouwiki.net

link.value: Touhou Shisouroku: Rinnosuke Morichika Promo Card

name.value: Le Grand Jeu du Peuple Migrateur

item.description:
"Winged Migration" in English
The game uses the principle of migration, you are a bird and you try to make your trip the best conditions, avoiding the pitfalls Racing game like Chutes and Ladders with cards events, issues, etc.

Each player is a migratory bird. The goal is to achieve complete its migration and reconstruct the puzzle bird as quickly as possible.
Once a player has met the six pieces of his puzzle, he must go to the finish to win the game having completed its "migration".

Player rolls the dice and move forward or backward

Each player has 40 cards that make up its game cards are either characters (heroes, village ...), magic, creatures, objects or places, all from the world of Lanfeust of Troy.
Each player represents a wise man who manages to start a group of villagers. Group that, throughout the game, grew in size and weapon, gets help from creatures, use of magic, visits to weaken the enemy wise.

The goal is to be the strongest or least injured at the end of the game.

In turn, each player performs in succession all the following phases:
1. managing the presence of heroes
2. care management of the characters and creatures
3. draws 2 cards
4. completion of 6 shares of its choice (ask a character, a creature, make use of magic, give an object to a character, use an action (the power) of a character placed in his camp ...
During these six stocks, the adversary can achieve in one and only.
5. launch an attack (either a general attack with all his forces, an attack with all characters flying and flying creatures, an attack against creature creature).
6. managing the presence of heroes
7. return of the hero in the neutral zone
8. discard any cards from his hand.

Once the player has completed all its phases, it is his opponent to do the same. And so on until the end of the game that occurs when a player received 10 wounds or one player has more cards in his deck.

Contents in the starter decks:

 2 sets of 40 cards (each set includes 28 common cards, 9 cards unusual and rare 3)
 40 chips (20 "P", 20 "Axes")
 A 6-sided dice
 1 Rulebook 23-page

Anzio: Operation Shingle covers the initial Allied landings on the 22nd January to the failure of the second German offensive, Operation Seitensprung, to eliminate the beachhead on the 1st March. The whole campaign can be replayed as well as several scenarios covering key parts of the battle. The game also allows alternative plans to be explored such as the original plan for the US 504th parachute regiment to be airdropped just outside Carroceto on the Via Anziate.

Extract from draft design notes...

…In order to calculate the hex grid needed I looked into the area required to deploy regimental sized units. German, American and British regimental units varied in size and composition, and by 1944 most units were suffering some level of depletion of manpower. Couple this with documented doctrinal frontages rarely being achieved on the ground and the calculation of accurate frontages becomes very problematic. A German infantry division in 1944 had three infantry regiments as well as an assortment of artillery, support and HQ companies and battalions. Each German infantry regiment consisted of two battalions. Bull (2005) states a German battalion in an attack frontage would occupy 400-1000m, and Rottman (2004) has their defensive frontage as 800-2000m. Disregarding any particular formations if these two battalions were placed in line the regiment would need:

German Regimental Frontages 
Attack 800-2000m ½ mile to 1¼ miles 
Defense 1600-4000m 1 mile to 2½ miles

British brigades (equivalent to regiments) and US regiments were somewhat larger than their German counterparts, having an additional infantry battalion. Doctrine would seldom recommend placing all of a regiments units in line, with some elements held back in reserve, so using with the above German calculation offers a useful yardstick.

The next design problem then emerged, how to simulate the different frontages of units and the particular advantages and disadvantages of each? Units in a defensive frontage should be able to defend a longer front and have some defensive advantage. Units in an attack frontage should be able to concentrate their strength and have the advantage of easier movement. The game simulates different frontages by allowing units to be within a single hex (attack frontage) or two hexes (defensive frontage) - additional aspects of the differing frontages are discussed later.

So using the German regimental frontage above I calculated that a single hex needed to be able to contain a regiment in an attack frontage of ½ to 1¼ miles. Taking into account that the allied formations were a little larger a scale of 1½ miles across each hex seems suitable. A regiment in a defensive frontage would cover around 3 miles. Each hex contains around 3½ square miles.

This hex grid was then placed over a map of the campaign area and adjustments made in order for the grid to fit…

Shooting game featuring a highly collectible Golliwog as the target. The idea is to shoot off his buttons and his eyes with your Air Pop-Gun.

Each player takes equal turns and the one with the most successes, wins.

A dexterity game in the mould of later games like Jenga. In this game players must build sticks on to a structure. As the sticks get higher, it becomes increasingly more difficult. The sticks are rounded like a straw which increases the difficulty level even higher.

Three dice decide which colours you need to take. Red sticks are the longest, blue sticks are medium length and green are the smallest.

Your turn is against the clock so you need to be pretty fast. If you knock down the stick tower, you lose that game. Play as many games as you want and the winner is the one with fewest losses.

Straightforward target game but with some flair for relating to the title. In the 18th century, coach travellers were often accosted by highwaymen and the Dover Road was a popular haunt, lying as it does between London and the port of Dover.

The targets, in period dress, are the coach itself, one alarmed passenger, one passenger who has just been shot and the highwayman.

The gun is operated by a rubber band but just look at the appearance, as near as they could get to an 18th century pistol.

The winner is the one with the most hits after the game ends.

El Bazar junior version.

Simple game in which players are trying to make something that they have on drawn tile (an animal, an object, a thing) using wooden elements. When the opponent guesses what you are building you both score a point. If not, next players is trying to make others to guess.

Text on the backside of the box:
How can a plane, a watering can or even a doll be presented using wooden shapes? Guaranteed giggles for the whole family...

Contents:

 120 tiles (toys, animals and objects)
 17 wooden shapes
 sand timer

City of Horror is a backstabbing survival-horror game. As in classic zombie movies, a shambling horde is invading the city. The goal is to survive the assault. (Un)fortunately, surviving often means sacrificing some of your fellow players to the undead...

Each player controls several characters with different abilities; these characters can move to various limited-capacity locations, which they can then barricade and scavenge for items and weapons. Critical situations, such as zombies breaking in and eating a character, are resolved using a vote.

The basic game mechanisms are the same as in Mall of Horror (also designed by Nicolas Normandon), but City of Horror differs in both materials and game play in a number of ways: the city map changes each game, twenty characters are included, they can use antidotes (or die), action cards become scarce as the game goes on, you can gain points with stuff other than surviving characters...

name.value: Squad Seven II: Le spectre d'Imhotek

item.description:
Second game in the Squad Seven saga.

This time the adventure takes place in the great desert of northern Sudan. The Squads explore the mysterious ruins of a temple buried under the sands in order to find the fabulous treasures, but also something else ... may be evidence that we are not alone in the universe and it may already be among us. Clues are hidden on the game cards.

Players choose their squad and enter the desert and take the turns to reveal cards, which may show treasure or various dangers. Many cards require the player to shoot a target or run round the table before a scream is heard on the soundtrack CD. If they fail, they lose a member of their squad.

The player who recovers the most treasure wins the game.

One of the type of game that the British, in particular, liked to play.

Each horse is attached to a length of string. By 'jiggling' the string, your horse can be made to move forward and, when a jump is reached, a different use of the string will allow your horse to 'jump' the fence. A fair amount of dexterity and finesse is needed with the aforementioned actions. The horses have two bases you might say, one flat and one rounded (it works exactly the same as a wheel would).

The first to finish the course, wins.

Speedway was so popular in Britain in the 1930's, many games reflected this.

This is a simple roll and move game. If your bike lands on one of many illustrated spaces, you must follow the instructions.

First to reach the finish-line, wins.

The game consists of a board with 6 holes which stands on two wooden blocks and in each of the holes hangs a bell. There are 2 large and 6 small tiddleywinks. The idea of the game is to propel your counters, Tiddleywinks fashion, and you score points for each tiddleywink that you fire through the holes with bonus scores for ringing the bells on the way through.

The rules are on a sheet attached to the inside of the box.

Highest score wins.

An action game for two football fans.

The board features several indentations which are long and thin. Each indentation has a player attached, and by moving levers at your end of the table, you can slide your footballer forward or back in order to 'kick' the ball. The ball is magnetic so that it is attracted to the nearest indentation once it has been kicked.

The winner is the one with the most goals after a pre-agreed time limit has expired.
Monopoly set in Buxtehude, Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Erlangen, in Germany.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Fehmarn, in Germany.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bonn, in Germany.

item.description: Monopoly with Borussia Dortmund, the famous soccer team from Germany. All the traditional elements of rolling, moving, purchasing, earning, and spending.

A spin and move game. The object of the game is to be the first to reach the jump space by exact spin and then descend by parachute to the landing finish area. Players spin the indicator in turn and then move along the "Take off Run" the number of spaces indicated. Any number of pieces can be on the same space. You must follow the instructions on any space that you land on. You must reach the space marked JUMP by exact spin, and when you do, you must remain there until you spin a 6 on a following turn to descend by parachute to the landing field and win the game

A simple trivia game where players need to know the countries to flags they see and be able to locate the country on the world map.

Players take turns naming a country of which they are shown a flag on a card. If they name the country correctly and can point to it on the world map, they can choose to claim the card as a point and pass the turn to the next player. Alternatively, they can choose to play for a second point by answering 3 of 5 multiple-choice questions concerning this country correctly. If they answer fewer than 3 questions correctly, they get 0 points this round.

The Presidential is a game of strategy played with dice and chance cards on a beautifully designed map of the U.S. showing the Electoral College votes of each state. Two teams, Democrats and Republicans, fight for control of state delegations to ultimately win more than 270 electoral votes. The Presidential is an entertaining and educational family game -- fun for both students (13+) and adults. You may not know how the Electoral College works, but you'll enjoy the excitement of playing for the most powerful job in the world!

The Play of the Game

The 2 teams decide which side will be the Republicans and which side will be the Democrats. The Republicans take the 150 red votes (chips) and the 3 red dice. The Democrats take the 150 blue votes (chips) and the 3 blue dice. The teams then decide how much time there is until election day by selecting a number of weeks until the election. One each turn, each team must decide whether they will go Fundraising or Campaigning.

Fundraising
There are 4 states where a candidate can fund raise (California, New York, Florida and Texas). The team decides which state they would like to fund raise in and then rolls 2 dice.

If a team rolls a 9, they have 9 votes to distribute. At least 1/2 the votes must stay in the fundraising state.

The team then draws a Politics Card, follows the instructions, and returns the card face-down to the bottom of the deck. The Politics Cards offer many rewards and a few penalties to the teams. They are similar to rolling another die.

Politics Cards
Here are a few examples of the Politics Cards:

 Silicon Valley tycoons host a successful fundraiser for you. Add 6 votes to California.
 You receive a 100% approval rating from the NRA. Win 5 votes in Texas.
 A popular blogger unveils pictures of your opponent’s wife buying a brand new Bentley. Add 3 votes to Michigan.
 You are spotted wearing a Red Sox hat while prepping for a debate. Your opponent adds 3 votes to New York.




Campaigning
If a team chooses to campaign, the team selects and announces the 3 states they will campaign in on that turn. Each state may only be visited once each turn. The team then rolls 3 dice. The team then decides which die corresponds to each state and contributes those votes to that state.

Votes
Each chip equals 1 vote. Votes are gained through the roll of the dice and the Politics Cards. At any one time, each state is Republican (Red), Democrat (Blue) or neutral. The votes in a state represent the net amount of chips that have been allocated by both parties.

End of the Game 
When time is up (the number of weeks that was selected have passed), there may be several states that are undecided (still neutral) either because they are in a tie or no team has campaigned in them or allocated them fund raising money. At that point, a neutral state is selected and each team rolls a die. The highest die wins the state and the electoral votes go to that team. If there is a tie roll, the teams roll again. The team with the highest number of electoral votes after all the neutral states have been awarded to either team wins the game.

Publisher's description:

Earth is being attacked by alien invaders. Can you defend it or will your Battle Cruisers be pulverised by the Invaders' Star Ships? Try this exciting 2000AD game and see just how ready you are for combat in the vast depths of outer space.

Abstract Strategy game given away in prog 233 of 2000AD. Players move their pieces around the triangular board in an effort to surround an opponents piece on all three sides, thereby eliminating that piece. The game is won when an opponent is reduced to two pieces.

User Summary

Each turn, a player can combine a tile in his hand with some more in the table, being the sum 15. If he can do that, he take all the tiles for himself. If he can't make 15, he discards one tile.
After all the players have used his tiles, the scoring phase begins, adding point for haver certain tiles (yellow 7 by example), having three cards of the same color, most red tiles, or other combinations. The first player that reaches 60 points, wins.

name.value: Supply Lines of the American Revolution: The Northern Theater, 1775-1777

item.description:
"Supply Lines of the American Revolution: The Northern Theater, 1775-1777" is a two-player game of supply, logistics, and deceit set during the first three years of the American Revolutionary War. One player, called the Patriot Player, controls the forces and destiny of the rebellious Americans; the other, the Crown Player, seeks to bring the rebels to their senses. The exact Victory Conditions of the game may vary depending on which historical events the players choose to re-enact.

Many aspects of warfare have been abstracted to focus squarely on issues of supply: protecting, moving, capturing, and effectively using it to further your goals and frustrate those of your opponent. Supplies come in two flavors, and are represented on-board by wooden cubes. Food Supply is expended to move your units, and War Supply to fight.

There is no hidden information, other than what your opponent intends to do, but flexible movement rules allow for considerable bluffing and misdirection. The game rewards boldness but also punishes the slightest error-- that is, if your opponent is clever enough to capitalize on it.

item.description:
The Maidens of the kingdom keep disappearing. As an aspiring Hero, your job is to rescue them. You must battle the Monsters that have been capturing the Maidens. But you are not the only aspiring Hero trying to rescue the Maidens. Can you rescue the most Maidens and become the Greatest Hero in the kingdom?

Monsters and Maidens is a fun, easy-to-learn dice game with nine fully customized six-sided dice. Players play the role of the Hero trying to rescue the Maidens from the Monsters.

By rolling the dice and comparing the results, players determine the success or failure of their mission. Players may have some rescued Maidens but decide to push their luck and roll the dice again in an attempt to rescue even more. If they aren't careful, though, they will be overtaken by the Monsters and lose some or even all of their rescued Maidens.

name.value: Red White & Blue Racin' Stock Car Action Game

item.description:
-From Plaay.com website:

"RED WHITE & BLUE RACIN' sports simulation board game offers a unique way of re-creating a pro stock car race. Instead of tediously checking every car, every lap, the game uses a "highlight reel" method of generating exciting race action. You get right to "good stuff!" NO math exercises or constant index calculations and re-calculations--this game is NOT about crunching numbers. It's about high-octane thrills and super-charged race day drama! The result? A full race in as little as 45 minutes, packed with everything fans love about big-time pro stock car racing!

"RED WHITE & BLUE RACIN' offers an assortment of different stock car experiences. The game comes with an "all star" set of driver cards representing stars of the past decade. For an additional charge, you can purchase a set of cards based specifically on last year's racing season, including everyone from the champion in the point standings to the drivers who ran only a race or two, and track cards for every racing venue at which a points race was held. There's also a "Stars of the 1980s" card set, allowing you to revive memories of racing's exciting past. Or create your OWN pro racing universe with a card set from our fictional pro stock car circuit, Stock Car Racing America--or SCRAM for short!"

RW&B Racin' allows you to play through a race, including qualifying, with the use of 6 dice and a game chart. Each turn a section of drivers, top, middle or bottom will be "highlighted" and drivers from the group will get a chance to move up in the race or maybe even take the lead! But along with the excitment of the race comes "trouble" which can lead to a trip to the pits or even taking a driver out of the race.

Utilizing a simple yet elegant system, each driver is rating on gas (passing), brake (defending against getting passed) as well as 6 racing skills. Also represented is how good a driver is at qualifying as well as how good the pit crew is at fixing the damage along the way. It is a quick system to learn, but you will be amazed at how it captures the essence of stock car racing.

For more information and for a more detailed description of a couple of turns, check out the Plaay.com website.

item.description:
The game consists of a board with holes in. Each hole scores a certain number of points. At the back of the board, a three-dimensional 'slide' is erected. Into the top of this slide, a player in his turn, drops a ball. The ball will bounce around the circus clowns at either side of the slide and, eventually, come out at the bottom and score points when it settles into one of the holes.

The points available range from 5 to 100, the latter hole being right in the middle of the board.

The one who earns the most points, wins.

You make the tour of the postman in answering questions about the North and passing of the cult scenes from the movie with the same name.

The game board shows town of Bergues. During the postman, the players will go through different stages, symbolized by the iconic scenes from the movie.

To be the winner of the game, simply answer correctly the questions on the Northern Department and on the film.

Contents:

 220 cards
 6 cyclists
 a game board

BATTLEMAGE is a fantasy wargame for two or more players. Each person controls a small warband of warriors, each led by a powerful Battlemage. You are fighting for power and glory, but more than that you are fighting for control of the world of Ra'al.

A game of BATTLEMAGE is fought between two warbands, each led by a powerful spellcaster called a Battlemage. The game is played on a tabletop with miniature figurines.

The game uses six-sided dice to resolve the conflict. Each figure (or 'warrior' as the game calls them) has it's own set of statistics that define how good it is at fighting: MV (move), ATT (attack), DEF (defence) and W (wounds). Additionaly, they may have special rules that let them do unusual things, such as make ranged attacks, use powers, or fly through the air, to name but a few.

The book contains five different warbands, each led by a different Battlemage. They include the Whiterock Loyalists, the Shadow Academy, the Cult of the Black Wind, The Horde of Seven Peaks and the Ghostwood Raiders.

Campaign rules are also include with the game, so that your warriors can improve with each battle.

item.description:
Objective: collect as many points (stars) as possible; alternative: be the first reaching target space with a matching number
 - moving by turn; similar to 'Snakes and Ladders' -
• move according die roll - no kick out, meeples can be put on same space

• first one reaching target space (96) gets the big star slide

A very old-fashioned game even in 1936. I mean the rules, not the sparkling illustrations by V.T.Hamlin.

You have to get to the end of the trail. A spinner is used rather than a die. You move as directed by the spinner. If you land on a special space, you must follow the instructions. If you land on the same space as another player, that player must go back 5 spaces.

First to the end of the track (by exact spin, of course), wins.

Based on the popular videogame and designed by Uwe Rosenberg, players in Farmerama use action cards to sow and harvest crops (carrots, hay, oats, corn) to feed their livestock (sheep, pigs, cow, horse) and earn victory points. On each player's board, a rotating wheel indicates where and when actions can take place, and another central wheel that affects all players indicates what yields they can expect. These wheels change over time, creating constantly shifting situations that players must navigate.

Buyers of the board game will also receive free resources to spend in the videogame.

item.description:
The object of the game is to control the most number of Space Craft at the end of the game.

On your go you roll 2 dice, add them together, and place your Space Craft on the corresponding space on the board, if it is not already occupied. If you roll a 7 you occupy the Moon with your large Moon Base token, this allows you to control the other Space Craft. While occupying the moon you may replace any of your opponent's pieces with a piece of your own colour, provided that you roll the correct number.

When all the areas numbered 2 to 12 are occupied the game ends and the player with the greater number of his colour markers is the winner.

Follow the road of knowledge with Fred and Jamy and let yourself be guided by the DVD to arrive first at the end of the road! 850 questions on five topics around the Earth and the Universe. Questions and explanations images with almost 350 experts from the program.

Contents: 

 1 board, 
 6 pawns, 
 an interactive DVD, 
 220 cards

C'est pas Sorcier version with ecological questions.

The objective of this quiz game is to return to the Studio first while absorbing a load of knowledge! Along the way, the players must answer questions. Each card includes a question, three wrong answers, the right answer and most importantly its explanation!

Board game for teenagers with CD included.

2-5 called fans compete with their knowledge of the superstars.
They are singer, stylist, manager, journalist and actress. Each turns must to collect stars in a bending test players answer questions from the four themes:

That evil spirits do not stir, each wins: if the rival is fulfilling its mission, it will be rewarded with a Fate card.

The nine worlds of Norse and Anglo-Germanic myth comprise the battleground for this area control game.

In the game Nine Worlds, players struggle to take control of these worlds, spending action points to add or remove armies, move them between the worlds, or banish them to Helheim. Control of a world gives access to world powers that players can use to win the game. Victory relates to the numbers of armies that players have in the Nine Worlds along with controlling or disputing control of as many worlds as possible.

item.description:
Play as a pirate, Captain of your own ship! Your goal is to obtain the most gold: the pirating way! In game you will: obtain precious treasures, hold prisoners captive, blast your opponents with cannons, and board enemy ships to steal their booty!

C&C uses a unique cannon combat mechanic where players must find or trade for gunpowder and ammunition in order to fire their cannons. Players can use cannonballs to sink enemy ships, chain-shot to make players lose turns (to repair their masts!), or grapeshot to clear the opponent's deck of crew.

Crew are used for boarding enemy ships to steal their cargo. Crew can be equipped with pistols, muskets, rapiers, or cutlasses in order to increase their chance of success. If victorious, crew are able to steal cards from the opposing player, whether that be supplies or gold. Treasure cards will trade hands multiple times before the next Port! card is found where the players can take a breather before the next round of raids and cannon bombardments begin.

This is a dice and card game that relies heavily on luck. In this sense, its best suited for casual gamers who are looking for a medium length game (30-60 minutes) that has excitement in every turn.

The game includes rules, two D6 dice, and 136 poker-size cards.
